resources.string: The Water for the World Workshop introduces participants to the issues of clean water access and how local economy, geography and literacy are all connected. Using this app, you will try to build a water filter to access clean water for yourself!
Many people in the world drink dirty water and get sick or die.\nYour challenge is to build a water filter to turn the glass of water
Press NEXT to start the challenge
Now you have tried to build a filter you will realise how difficult it is for people in sub-Saharan Africa to access to clean water

By now you will be aware of some of the issues around access to clean water in sub-Saharan Africa. Press NEXT to answer questions about the exercise for your teacher or presenter or press skip to end the workshop.\nPress NEXT to start the challenge or press SKIP to end the workshop.
There are approaching 8 billion people in the world. How many of them do you think do not have access to clean drinking water in their home?
Yes! around 800 million people - 1 in 10 of the world’s population - don’t have clean drinking water within a 30-minute trip from their home and 1 in 4 (2 billion!) don’t have it in their home
A: Living on less than $2.50 a day\nHow many people do you think live on less than $2.50 a day?
Yes! 1 Billion people in the world live in Extreme Poverty – think what you could buy with $2.50 – what could you eat and how would your or your parents be able to pay your rent
Where do most of the people without clean water access live?
Yes, most of the people in the world living without clean water live in Sub-Saharan Africa – the part of Africa south of the Sahara
Where do most of the people in extreme poverty live?
Yes, most of the people in the world living in extreme poverty live in Sub-Saharan Africa – the part of Africa south of the Sahara. Click NEXT to see how poverty varies around the world.
How did the money and literacy rate you were given for each affect your ability to build a water filter?
Do you think water and its use around the world is fair and equal? Should people have the same access to water everywhere?
What can you do in your daily life to conserve water?
What is the most important thing you have learned doing this activity?

The literacy rate is defined by the percentage of the population of a given age group that can read and write. As you can see on the map, the lack of education in Sub-Saharan Africa is a problem.
